body.p: The C SDK does not create any threads or perform any internal locking. The library assumes a single threaded event loop (or reactive) model.

section.title: Using a handle in a Single Thread
section.p: You may use a single handle (lcb_t object) within a single thread without any additional code or settings. All lcb_t objects are independent, and multiple lcb_t objects can exist in multiple threads.
The bundled cbc-pillowfight uses multiple threads, creating a single lcb_t per thread.
You should use a single handle per thread (and per-bucket) if your application makes heavy use of Couchbase and you wish to parallelize over several concurrent TCP connections.

body.section: Using a Handle from Different ThreadsIt is possible to use a single handle from multiple threads, however the handle may not be accessed by multiple threads at the same time. This means that you must ensure that any C SDK call with the same lcb_t is guarded by a lock (or similar mechanism) ensuring that other threads do not also attempt to access the handle at the same time. This means, for example, that additional operations cannot be added (e.g. lcb_store3) while the library is waiting for responses to arrive (lcb_wait).pthread_mutex_lock(lock); lcb_wait(instance); pthread_mutex_unlock(lock);You should create a single library handle (per bucket) if your application does not make heavy use of Couchbase. If you find that your application's threads are often blocked on lcb_wait calls, then consider using a single handle per thread.

Using with fork()
If your process forks, beware that lcb_t instances are not usable from both child and parent and processes. Each library instance will still maintain the parent's open sockets and file descriptors. In the event that both instances are used concurrently, the TCP stream will end up sending data from both instances, causing strange behavior and often crashes.
In order to ensure that parent and child processes work with the C SDK:
If possible, ensure that any fork() is called before any invocation to lcb_create
If you wish to use the lcb_t in the child process, then you may not use the parent instance. This also means that you will not be able to call lcb_destroy, effectively leaking memory for the given lcb_t
If you wish to use the lcb_t in the parent process then you may not use the child instance. As above, this also means that you will not be able to call lcb_destroy in the child, effectively leaking memory. Often, it may seem like lcb_destroy can properly reclaim the memory by the unused handle, but it is possible for lcb_destroy and some I/O implementations to flush any pending I/O operations before cleanup.
